We accomplish this goal by striking the balance between safeguarding the personal safety of judges and preserving transparency and accountability in the judiciary. We thank our bipartisan group of colleagues who joined us in honoring Daniel Anderl’s life.
This bill strengthens our democracy and ensures that federal judges can perform their solemn duty of administering equal justice under the law without fear of retaliation.

We swore to act swiftly, and to never stop fighting until we passed legislation that paid tribute to Daniel’s legacy by protecting judges and their families from future threats, and tonight we kept our promise—taking a decisive step towards protecting our federal judges.

On July 19, 2020, an aggrieved former litigant targeted NJ’s U.S. District Court Judge Esther Salas after finding her home address online — injuring her husband Mark Anderl & killing their beloved son Daniel. In the days that followed, we made a personal vow to Judge Salas.

BREAKING: With tonight's passage of the Daniel Anderl Judicial Security and Privacy Act, I kept my promise to Judge Esther Salas to honor her beloved Daniel's legacy. We remain forever indebted to Judge Salas and Mark for turning their grief into purpose.https://t.co/RVbYTk2kJ3

As long as I'm in the Senate, I will never stop fighting to honor the victims of Sandy Hook & Uvalde & Las Vegas & Orlando & Parkland & El Paso & Sutherland Springs & Pittsburgh Tree of Life and for the right of every American to live free from fear of gun violence.

10 years after Sandy Hook, as we continue to grieve for the lives senselessly cut short, I'm comforted in knowing that the landscape has changed drastically over this decade.

The NRA is weaker than ever, and the overwhelming majority of Americans support commonsense gun reform.

There's no question these measures have saved lives, but it's nowhere near enough.

We have a lot more to do, including banning assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, banning silencers, expanding background checks, and much more.

21 states passed community violence intervention laws 37 took up domestic violence prohibitions
20 embraced "red flag" protection measures
29 toughened background checks
18 approved laws that make it more difficult for children and young adults to access firearms
According to @GiffordsCourage, 525 “significant gun safety laws” have been adopted at the state level, with nearly every state in the country taking at least one significant step forward:
Along the way, thanks to the tireless work of advocates, survivors, and the incredible strength and courage of victims' families, we've also seen significant progress at the state and local level.

Although Congressional Republicans have spent much of the last decade offering "thoughts and prayers" in reaction to tragedies rather than doing anything to prevent them, we finally saw a breakthrough this year when we passed the first federal gun reform bill in decades.

Like most Americans, I truly hoped the tragic events of Sandy Hook would be the tectonic shift we needed to shake the GOP free from the NRA's stranglehold & push Congress to finally act on gun reform. Today, the NRA's grip hasn't completely faded, but we've made much progress.

10 years ago, the collective heart of our nation broke with the news of 26 lives, including 20 young children, ended too soon & still, too many officials refused to act on gun violence.

Today, we remember those lost and recommit to the fight to end gun violence in their memory. https://t.co/w7yXIOcKrB

Our bill was carefully crafted, with the advice of experts like @tribelaw to ensure that we protect 1st Amendment rights, including the press' ability to do the important work of exposing judicial conflicts of interest.

The Daniel Anderl Judicial Security and Privacy Act is named for the son of Judge Esther Salas, who was shot and killed by an aggrieved plaintiff who targeted her as a Latina federal judge. What happened to Judge Salas, her husband, and their son, should never happen again.
Matters of public concern, such as previous places of employment would continue to be available to journalists.

It's time to ensure that we give our public servants a hand out of the hole that student debt can become. These changes are the first step in what I hope will be continuing progress to achieve this goal. /7

They also prevent borrowers from being penalized when consolidating their loans by weighing the average of existing qualifying payments towards PSLF, whereas consolidation previously wiped out all of a borrower’s progress towards loan forgiveness. /6

These changes will allow public servants in education and public health, including teachers, nurses & social workers, many who are required to pursue advanced degrees while working, to receive credit for the time they spend working towards those career requirements. /5

I’ve also called for periods of deferment and forbearance to count towards PSLF, including in-school deferment to count towards PSLF, and these rules allow borrowers to get credit for these periods. /4

After years where only a percentage of PSLF applicants were approved because complicated rules made it nearly impossible for firefighters, nurses, and others to qualify because they made the wrong types of payments - they will finally have a path to forgiveness under PSLF. /3

For months, I've called on @POTUS to make the changes under the PSLF waiver permanent, and this week's announcement codifies key parts, allowing borrowers to receive credit for payments made late, in installments, or lump sum. /2

🧵 I've long been pushing the Biden Administration to go beyond the Limited PSLF waiver and make permanent fixes to help borrowers access the benefits they've earned. I'm proud to see the admin announcing many of the changes I've called for. /1 https://t.co/d1a7zot0of

And to those who dare call this bill amnesty and preach xenophobia & hate: the status quo deprives us of the economic benefits of inclusive, lasting reform. Enough with this notion that immigration reform is somehow a loss to Republicans and not a win for America.

This bill will bring the 11 million out of the shadows, give them the opportunity to pass criminal background and national security checks, secure Lawful Prospective Immigrant Status, eventually apply for Green Cards & after 8 years begin the naturalization process.

We know the path forward will demand negotiations with the other side, but we will never win an argument we don’t have the courage to make. We must make our case for bold, inclusive and lasting immigration reform.

The 11 million undocumented are not "bad hombres.” They are Dreamers & TPS holders, farmworkers & meatpackers, relatives, friends and essential workers who kept our economy afloat in this pandemic. Immigration reform will make America stronger.

I’ve worked on immigration reform for nearly 30 years. The reason we haven’t gotten it done yet is not because Americans don’t support it. They do. The problem is we’ve capitulated too quickly to fringe voices that yell "amnesty" at anything accepting the humanity of immigrants.

Today, @RepLindaSanchez  & I unveiled the U.S. Citizenship Act, legislation that brings to life @POTUS’s plan to restore humanity and American values to our immigration system after four years of Trump’s hateful horror show.
